Battlemages are warriors who enhance their combat with some form of magic. The nature of the magic can vary greatly between battlemages, often imitating that of powerful casters such as druids, clerics and wizards. While their magic arsenal rarely compares to more specialist mages, when used in combination with their martial talents, they can make formidable opponents that can easily turn the tide of battle.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you augment your martial prowess with the ability to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} of the Player's Handbook for the general rules of spellcasting. There are many sources and methods of magic which you can tap into, from the primal forces of nature itself, to the weave of the multiverse, to your own unique blood. Choose the nature of your magic by selecting a spell list; {@filter artificer|spells|class=artificer}, {@filter bard|spells|class=bard}, {@filter cleric|spells|class=cleric}, {@filter druid|spells|class=druid}, {@filter paladin|spells|class=paladin}, {@filter ranger|spells|class=ranger}, {@filter sorcerer|spells|class=sorcerer}, {@filter warlock|spells|class=warlock} or {@filter wizard|spells|class=wizard}. Your choice also determines your spellcasting ability: Intelligence for artificer or wizard; Wisdom for cleric, druid or ranger; or Charisma for bard, paladin, sorcerer, or warlock.
{@note Your DM may allow additional spell lists, they decide the associated spellcasting ability.}

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from your chosen spell list. You learn an additional battlemage cantrip of your choice from your chosen list at 10th level. If you chose the paladin or ranger list, you may choose your cantrips from the cleric or druid lists respectively.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Battlemage Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your battlemage spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell shield} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell shield} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know three 1st-level battlemage spells of your choice from your chosen list.

The Spells Known column of the Battlemage Spellcasting table shows when you learn more battlemage spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the battlemage spells you know with another spell of your choice from your chosen spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Your spellcasting ability for your battlemage spells is determined by your chosen spell list. In addition, you use your spellcasting ability modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a battlemage spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Bonded Implement
entries: At 3rd level, you learn a ritual that creates a magical bond between yourself and one weapon or shield. You perform the ritual over the course of 1 hour, which can be done during a short rest. The weapon or shield must be within your reach throughout the ritual, at the conclusion of which you touch the weapon or shield and forge the bond.

Once you have bonded a weapon or shield to yourself, you can use the weapon or shield as a spellcasting focus for your battlemage spells. You can't be disarmed of that weapon or shield unless you are incapacitated. If it is on the same plane of existence, you can summon that weapon or shield as a bonus action on your turn, causing it to teleport instantly to your hand.

You can have up to two bonded weapons or shields, but can summon only one at a time with your bonus action. If you attempt to bond with a third weapon or shield, you must break the bond with one of the other two.

subclassFeature.name: Battlemage Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level battlemage fighter {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can shift your magical focus, choosing a different spell list for your Spellcasting feature. If any of your battlemage spells or cantrips are not part of the new list, you must replace them with different spells and cantrips of the same level from the new list. Your spellcasting ability also changes to the one associated with the new list.

subclassFeature.name: War Magic
entries: Beginning at 7th level, when you use your action to cast a cantrip, you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action.
In addition, attacks with your Bonded Implements count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Strike
entries: At 10th level, you learn how to make your weapon strikes undercut a creature's resistance to your spells. When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, that creature has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes against a spell you cast before the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Surge
entries: At 15th level, you further augment your combat prowess with magic. Whenever you finish a long rest, choose one of the surge effects listed below. Until the end of your next long rest, whenever you use your Action Surge, you gain the benefits of the chosen effect.

items: {@b Assault Surge.} Whenever you hit a creature with a weapon attack as part of the additional action, the attack deals an extra {@dice 1d8} force damage.
{@b Blink Surge.} Immediately before or after the additional action, you can teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.
{@b Focused Surge.} You have advantage on ability checks you make as part of the additional action.
{@b Guiding Surge.} If you use your additional action to take the Help action to aid an ally in attacking a target, you can choose two targets instead of one.

subclassFeature.name: Improved War Magic
entries: Starting at 18th level, when you use your action to cast a spell, you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Feast Domain
entries: Food is about more than just sustenance. The act of gathering around the fire or table to share food and stories brings communities together and forms a bond greater than the sum of its parts.
Deities of the Feast could include, but are not limited to; Dagda, Dionysus, Olga and Demeter.

entries.caption: Feast Domain Spells
rows: {@spell create food and water|phb}, {@spell motivational speech|ai}

subclassFeature.name: Gracious Host
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with {@item brewer's supplies|phb} and {@item cook's utensils|phb}. You can use either of these tools as a spellcasting focus for your cleric spells.
Additionally, you know the {@spell prestidigitation|phb} cantrip. It counts as a cleric cantrip for you, but it doesn't count against the number of cleric cantrips you know.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Halls of Merriment
entries: As an action, you can use your Channel Divinity to fill the area around you with the sounds and smells of a joyous feast for 1 minute or until you dismiss it (no action required). You choose a number of creatures equal to your proficiency bonus that you can see within 30ft of you to become intoxicated with the cheerful atmosphere of the feast. For the duration, the chosen creatures have advantage on any Charisma checks and saving throws they make, but have disadvantage on any Wisdom checks and saving throws they make. The effect ends early if you dismiss it on a creature if it is ever more than 30 feet from you.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Storing Snacks
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can produce a special snack or drink that is infused with magic. With {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, {@item cook's utensils|phb} or your {@item holy symbol|phb} in hand, you can produce a snack over the course of 10 minutes and store a single spell in it by expending a spell slot of a high enough level and providing any material components. The spell must be a cleric spell between 1st and 5th level that you have prepared, it must have a casting time of either 1 action or 1 bonus action and must be incapable of targeting more than one creature at the spell's current level. The snack lasts until it is consumed or until the end of your next long rest.

When a creature consumes the snack as an action, the spell is cast with them as the target. The spell uses your spellcasting ability. If the spell normally requires concentration, it doesn't require concentration in this case; the spell lasts for its full duration.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any {@class cleric|phb} cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: {@i 8th-level cleric {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}, which replaces the Potent Spellcasting feature}

You are blessed with divine might in battle. When a creature takes damage from one of your cantrips or weapon attacks, you can also deal {@dice 1d8} radiant damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Gourmet Snacks
entries: Starting at 17th level, when you roll for damage or healing on a spell cast using your Spell Storing Snacks feature, you can instead choose to deal maximum damage or healing, instead of rolling. Once you use this feature, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Null Domain
entries: Unlike many other clerics, you do not draw your power from a god, at least not in the typical sense. Your power may be drawn from the creatures and life around you. You may be a follower of a personification of nothingness, such as Chaos. You may have deep desire to oppose the influence of gods on the multiverse, using unorthodox methods to understand and imitate divine magic. You may even be a follower of a now dead god, holding on to the last remnants of their power.

However your power originates, you act as a siphon of divine and magical energy, sapping it from the world around you, absorbing, redirecting or even outright destroying it. Such clerics might violate the common understandings of the world and the gods, sometimes resulting in them becoming sources of great confusion, fear and even hatred. Though others may be as fascinated and awed by them as they are confused.
At each indicated cleric level, you add the listed spells to your spells prepared.

entries.caption: Null Domain Spells
rows: {@spell protection from evil and good|phb}, {@spell silvery barbs|scc}
{@spell aura of purity|phb}, {@spell ray of impotence|J:General}

subclassFeature.name: Divineless
entries: Starting when you choose this domain at 1st level, you have resistance to radiant and necrotic damage.

Additionally, you can use a broken remnant of an object that once represented worship, devotion or servitude as a spellcasting focus for your cleric spells. This could include a damaged {@item holy symbol|phb}, a severed chain, burned vestmets or holy books, shattered stained glass or even a piece of flesh or bone from a dead god.

subclassFeature.name: Energy Thief
entries: Starting at 1st level, when a creature you can see within 30 feet of you is targeted by a spell or magic effect that deals damage or restores hit points to it, you can use a reaction to forcibly draw some of the energy towards yourself. The damage or healing is then divided evenly between you and the target creature (this is calculated before resistances or other damage reductions). If you are concentrating on a spell when you use this reaction, this damage does not break your concentration.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to proficiency bonus, and you regain all uses at the end of a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Deny Power
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to weaken connections to sources of power and strength, especially external ones such as deities and other planes. As an action, you choose a number of creatures up to your proficiency bonus that you can see within 60 feet of you and force them to make a Wisdom saving throw. If a creature is a celestial, elemental, fey, fiend or undead, it has disadvantage on this saving throw. The DM may also decide that a creature has disadvantage if it draws powers from other beings or planes, such as clerics or warlocks.

A creature that fails this saving throw has disadvantage on attack rolls and other creatures have advantage on saving throws against the creature's spells and magic effects. These effects last for 1 minute or until you are {@condition incapacitated}. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, removing the effects on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Consume Spell
entries: Starting a 6th level, you can siphon magical energy from others and immediately redirect it. Whenever you successfully cause a spell to fail using the {@spell counterspell|phb} spell, you can cast a cantrip you know as part of the same reaction. The cantrip must have a casting time of 1 action or 1 bonus action and must target only yourself or only the target of the counterspell.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any {@class cleric|phb} cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: {@i 8th-level cleric {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}, which replaces the Potent Spellcasting feature}

You are blessed with divine might in battle. When a creature takes damage from one of your cantrips or weapon attacks, you can also deal {@dice 1d8} radiant damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Energy Thief
entries: Starting at 17th level, when you use your Energy Thief feature, you can choose to take all of the damage or healing, rather than dividing evenly between you and the target creature.
Additionally, you can choose to channel the damage or healing you would receive to a second willing creature you can see within 10ft of you instead.

subclassFeature.name: Time Domain
entries: The forces of time and entropy are some of the most powerful in the universe. Eventually time will consume everything, even the universe itself. The gods and goddesses who control the flow of time, such as Kronos or Talitus control the lives, deaths and fate of every being in existence. Followers of these deities can employ chronomancy to alter their fate and that of their allies.
At each indicated cleric level, you add the listed spells to your spells prepared.
{@note *If your DM allows, you can replace either the {@spell dimension door|phb} or {@spell freedom of movement|phb} spell in your time domain spells with the {@spell Time Stasis|Jackalope} spell.}

subclassFeature.name: Temporal Control
entries: Starting when you choose this domain at 1st level, you have advantage on your initiative rolls, provided you are not {@condition incapacitated}.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Rewrite History
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to rewrite a single moment in time.

When you or a creature you can see within 30ft of you rolls damage or healing, you can use your channel divinity as a reaction to force them to reroll a number of dice up to up to your Wisdom modifier, they must then take the result of the new rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Quickened Evasion
entries: At 6th level, you can control the flow of time to improve evasive capabilities for you or your allies. When you or a creature within 30ft of you is targeted by an attack roll or makes a Dexterity saving throw, you can use your reaction to add your wisdom modifier to the creature���s AC or saving throw. You can choose to use this feature after the die is rolled, but before the outcome is determined.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any {@class cleric|phb} cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: {@i 8th-level cleric {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}, which replaces the Potent Spellcasting feature}

You are blessed with divine might in battle. When a creature takes damage from one of your cantrips or weapon attacks, you can also deal {@dice 1d8} radiant damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Temporal Halt
entries: At 17th level, you learn the {@spell Time Stop} spell as a cleric spell and always have it prepared, it does not count towards your prepared spells. When you cast it as a cleric spell you can target one additional creature to be unaffected by the spell, allowing them to also use actions and move as normal for the duration of the spell. The spell ends for both of you if either of you perform any action that would end the spell for you, as described in the spell���s description.

subclassFeature.name: Optional Rule: Additional Domain Spells
entries: If your DM allows, you may add the {@spell Reality Break|egw} and {@spell Time Ravage|egw} spells to your cleric spell list.

subclassFeature.name: The Timeless One
entries: Your patron does not conform to the normal flow of time, they may even exist outside of time entirely. Followers of a timeless being can manipulate their own flow of time relative to the world around them, allowing them to move, act and even age at different rates.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Timeless One lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Timeless Warrior
entries: At 1st level, you acquire the training necessary to effectively arm yourself for battle. You gain proficiency with medium armor, shields, and martial weapons.

subclassFeature.name: Rush
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can enter a slightly different time stream to those around you, thereby improving your relative speed and reflexes. As a bonus action, you can trigger a rush provided you are not {@condition incapacitated} or wearing heavy armor. The rush lasts 1 minute but ends early if you are {@condition incapacitated} or choose to end it (no action required). For the duration of the rush, your speed is increased by 10ft and you have advantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws.
Additionally, whenever you trigger a rush, you choose one of the following forms, each form grants you additional benefits for the duration of the rush.

items: {@b Dancer.} You can use a bonus action to take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Dodge} action. You may also use this bonus action as part of the same one you use to trigger the rush.
{@b Strider.} {@quickref Difficult terrain||3} does not slow you down.
{@b Striker.} You can use a bonus action to gain advantage on your next attack roll within the same rush. You may also use this bonus action as part of the same one you use to trigger the rush.

entries: You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
When you reach 10th level in this class, each of your rush forms gain extra benefits.

subclassFeature.name: D��j�� Vu
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can briefly jump back in time a few seconds to act simultaneously with your past self. On your turn, you can take one additional action. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Delay Spell
entries: Starting at 10th level, when a spell that targets an area you can see, such as the {@spell fireball|phb} spell, you may use a reaction to freeze the spell in time for a short duration. The spell is still cast in the same area but will not take effect until you release it any point before the end of your next turn (no action required), potentially allowing creatures and objects to enter or leave the area before the spell is released. The spell is released early if you lose sight of the spell's area, if you are {@condition incapacitated|phb}, or you die. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Enhanced Rush
entries: At 10th level, each of your rush forms gain additional benefits for the duration of the rush.

items: {@b Dancer.} You can take a reaction on every turn in combat.
{@b Strider.} You gain a climbing speed and a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.
{@b Striker.} Your attack rolls score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or higher on the d20.

subclassFeature.name: Timeless Body
entries: Starting at 14th level, you no longer age unless you choose to, and you can't be aged magically. Additionally, you no longer need to breathe, eat, drink or sleep.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Timebreaker
entries: The laws of time are rigid and unmoving for even skilled mages, but with that rigidity comes brittleness. Where mages may attempt to subtly bend the laws of time, your focused fury can just break right through them. Exploiting these breaches, you can act in sequences that seem impossible to others, if they can even perceive them at all.

subclassFeature.name: Shatter Instinct
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you can bend or break the fabric of time to act sooner than you would otherwise. When you roll for initiative, you can add your Strength modifier to the result of the roll. You can only gain this benefit if you are raging or if enter your rage before doing anything else on your first turn.

subclassFeature.name: Split Attack
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can briefly split yourself across the same point in time, attacking multiple enemies at once. Once per turn, when you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can immediately make an additional melee attack against another creature within your reach. You must use the same weapon as you used for the first attack.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Instantaneous Break
entries: Starting at 6th level, your rage can break through the barriers of time, allowing you to finish tasks before others can even perceive you begin them. While raging, you can use a bonus action on your turn to prevent any creatures other than you taking reactions on the current turn. For this turn, you can also move through the space of other creatures, and it doesn't count as difficult terrain. If you end the turn in another creature's space, you are shunted to the last unoccupied space that you occupied, and both you and the creature take {@dice 1d8} force damage.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Splintered Action
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use a bonus action to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Grapple} or {@action Shove} action.

Additionally, once during a turn in which you use this bonus action, you can teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within 60 feet and that you have occupied at some point on the current turn. If you are grappling a creature, it must make a Charisma saving throw or be teleported with you. The DC for this saving throw is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier. You can teleport in this way a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Preemptive Realiation
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can react to attacks by jumping back a few seconds to attack first. When a creature you can see within 10 feet of you targets you with an attack, you can use a reaction to make one melee weapon attack against that creature. The creature is considered within reach regardless of your reach, and the attack ignores half and three-quarters cover. On a hit, the creature suffers the attack's effects before it can continue its own attack.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Chronal Fist
entries: Those who follow the Way of the Chronal Fist focus their knowledge and abilities on the temporal fabric of the multiverse, using martial arts to warp it to their benefit. With this knowledge, they can alter a creature's position and velocity in time.

subclassFeature.name: Dilation Strikes
entries: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, your unarmed strikes can alter the timestream of creatures you hit. Once per turn, when you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can choose to either increase or decrease the target's speed by 10ft until the start of your next turn. In addition, you can choose to forgo damage on the attack to increase or decrease the target's speed by an additional 10ft.

subclassFeature.name: Perfect Timing
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can subtly alter your perception of time to ensure you act at the perfect moment. When you make an ability check that uses your Dexterity modifier, you can expend 1 Ki Point to gain a bonus to the roll equal to your Martial Arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Chronal Dodge
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you or a willing creature you can see within 5 feet takes damage, you can use a reaction to jump the target forward through time a few seconds. The damage taken by the target is reduced by two rolls of your martial arts die, and the target is transported to a harmless demiplane outside of time and is incapacitated until the start of its next turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Fast Forward Fist
entries: Starting at 11th level, you can use your strike to attempt to force a creature forward through time. When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike or a monk weapon, you can spend 4 ki points to force that creature to make a Charisma saving throw. On a fail, the creature is hurled through a harmless demiplane between timelines, and is {@condition incapacitated}.

The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, returning to the space it left on a success, or appearing in the nearest unoccupied space if its space is occupied. The creature also returns early if you lose concentration (as if concentrating on a spell) If a creature is still in the demiplane after 1 minute, the effect no longer requires concentration and the creature returns to the space it left {@dice 1d12 * 4|1d12 x 4} hours after the moment it left. Either way, no time appears to have passed at all from the creature's perspective.

subclassFeature.name: Chronal Ki
entries: Starting at 17th level, you learn to split yourself across multiple timelines, performing all them simultaneously, before merging back into the original. Doing so allows you to enhance several your ki features as described below.

items: {@b {@i Flurry of Blows.}} When you use your Flurry of Blows, you can make three unarmed strikes rather than two. In addition, your unarmed strikes have a reach of 15 feet for the duration of the current turn.

{@b {@i Patient Defence.}} When you use your Patient Defence, once before the start of your next turn, when a creature targets you with an attack, you can make an unarmed strike against that creature before it can complete the attack, provided they are within reach of your unarmed strike and you are not {@condition incapacitated}. This unarmed strike does not cost a reaction. If this unarmed strike reduces the creature to 0 hit points, or otherwise leaves them unable to make the attack, the attack it made against you misses and you take no damage.

{@b {@i Step of the Wind.}} When you use your Step of the Wind, you can take both the {@action Dash} and {@action Disengage} action with the same bonus action. In addition, your speed increases by 10 feet for the duration of the current turn.

subclassFeature.name: Vermin
entries: The smaller beasts of of the world are often overlooked, or even despised, but not by you. You see the value in these creatures and thus have sought to befriend them. In return, they make resourceful allies.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Kin
entries: At 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill if you don't already have it.
Additionally, you can cast the {@spell animal messenger|phb} and {@spell speak with animals|phb} spells as rituals.

subclassFeature.name: Vermin Friend
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell find familiar} spell as a ritual and without proving material components. When you do so using this feature, you gain the following benefits:

items: You can communicate telepathically with your familiar and perceive through your familiar's senses as long as you are within 300ft of them.

When the familiar takes damage while within 300ft of you, you can use your reaction to temporarily dismiss them to a pocket dimension without taking the damage. You can then use an action to make them reappear as described in the spell's description.
Your familiar's proficiency bonus is equal to yours. The familiar also gains the benefits of any feature, such as Expertise, that doubles your proficiency bonus.

Your familiar is proficient with {@item thieves' tools|phb} and {@item dagger|phb|daggers}, and can use them even if its form normally couldn't. At the DM's discretion, they may also use other tiny items such as keys, quills or vials of poison.

When you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn, you can forgo one of your own attacks to allow your familiar to use their reaction to make one attack of their own. This attack can benefit from your Sneak Attack feature if it uses a natural weapon (such as Bite or Talons), or a finesse or ranged weapon. All the other rules for Sneak Attack still apply.

subclassFeature.name: Critter Horde
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can cast the {@spell conjure animals|phb} spell at 3rd-level without expending a spell slot. When you do so using this feature, you summon {@filter swarms of tiny beasts|bestiary|type=beast|tag=swarm|miscellaneous=} instead of beasts.
Once you use this feature, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Quick Extraction
entries: Starting at 13th level, your vermin friend can touch a non-magical object, that weighs 10lbs or fewer, and use an action to teleport it instantly to your open hand. The object can not be one that is worn or carried by a creature other than the familiar, and it must be on the same plane of existence as you. The familiar can also teleport itself to a space within 5ft of you as part of the same action along with any items it is wearing or carrying.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Critter Horde
entries: Starting at 17th level, when you cast {@spell conjure animals|phb} using your Critter Horde feature, you can cast it at 5th-level rather than 3rd-level.

subclassFeature.name: The Darkweaver
entries: Your patron is a powerful spider-like being from the depths of the Underdark. You serve the whims of an aranea, chwidencha, drider, gee'aantu, giant spider or even figures such as Arachne or Lolth.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Darkweaver lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Darkweaver Expanded Spells
rows: {@spell find steed|phb} (large or medium {@creature giant wolf spider} only), {@spell web|phb}
{@spell spirit guardians|phb} (appear as spiders), {@spell stinking cloud|phb}

subclassFeature.name: Nest Crawler
entries: At 1st level, you are acclimated to underground spider nests, you have a climbing speed equal to your walking speed, and you ignore movement restrictions caused by webbing.

Additionally, you have darkvision out to a range of 120 feet. In that radius, you can see in dim light as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

subclassFeature.name: Silk Spinner
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can use an action to produce webbing that takes the form of an item you choose from the following list; a {@item net|phb}, a {@item sack|phb}, {@item silk rope (50 feet)|phb}, a {@item sling|phb}, or a {@item whip|phb}. If your DM allows, you may also create any other non-magical item that could believably be made using spider webs. You are proficient with any weapons produced using this feature.

The maximum number of items you can produce with this feature at one time is equal to your proficiency bonus. If you try to exceed your maximum, the oldest item disintegrates, and then the new item is produced.

subclassFeature.name: Toxin Tolerance
entries: At 6th level, you gain resistance to poison damage and advantage on saving throws to avoid or remove the {@condition poisoned} condition.
When you reach 14th level in this class, you gain immunity to poison damage and the poisoned condition.

subclassFeature.name: Webslinger
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use a bonus action to fire a web to move objects and creatures. Choose an object or creature you can see within 30ft and choose one of the following effects.

items: {@b Pull.} You pull the target up to 15ft towards you. The target must be an object or creature that is large or smaller and is not fixed in place (such as a wall or tree). If you target a creature, or an object worn or carried by a creature, the creature can make a Strength saving throw against your warlock spell save DC to avoid this effect.

{@b Trip.} You pull the target {@condition prone.} The target must be a creature that is large or smaller. The creature can make a Strength saving throw against your warlock spell save DC to avoid this effect.

{@b Zip.} You pull yourself up to 15ft towards the target. The target must be an object or creature that is medium or larger or is fixed in place (such as a wall or tree). You also cannot use this effect if you are {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}. If you target a creature, or an object worn or carried by a creature, the creature can make a Dexterity saving throw against your warlock spell save DC to avoid this effect.

subclassFeature.name: Quickweb
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you see a creature within 30ft (including yourself) take damage, you can use the Pull or Zip effect from your Webslinger feature as a reaction to attempt to move them, potentially having them avoid the damage. You can use the feature in this way a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Spider Bites
entries: Starting at 10th level, once per turn, when you hit a creature with an attack using a weapon or warlock cantrip, you can choose to apply one of the following additional effects.

items: {@b Terrifying Horde.} You summon a horde of spectral spiders to swarm over the creature. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your warlock spell save DC or be {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the creature can attempt the saving throw again, removing the condition on a success.

{@b Toxic Venom.} You deliver a potent venom through the attack. The creature must make a Constitution saving throw against your warlock spell save DC or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the creature can attempt the saving throw again, removing the condition on a success.

entries: You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Toxin Tolerance Improved
entries: At 14th level, you gain immunity to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Wall Walker
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can cast the {@spell spider climb|phb} spell at will, and without consuming a spell slot. When you do so, you can cast it on up to ten willing creatures, and you automatically pass saving throws to maintain concentration on this spell.

subclassFeature.name: The Dragon
entries: Dragons are among the most powerful beings on the material plane and sometimes beyond. The strongest dragons may take on mortal followers and grant them a share of their power.
Choose your patron���s dragon form or determine it randomly, using the Dragon Form table below.

entries.caption: Dragon Form
rows: Black Dragon, Blue Dragon, Dragon Turtle, Green Dragon, Red Dragon, Tiamat or White Dragon
Bahamut, Brass Dragon, Bronze Dragon, Copper Dragon or Gold Dragon
Amethyst Dragon, Crystal Dragon, Emerald Dragon, Moonstone Dragon, Sapphire Dragon, Sardior or Topaz Dragon

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Dragon lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The Dragon Expanded Spells table shows the dragon spells that are added to the warlock spell list for you, along with the spells associated in the table with your patron���s dragon form: chromatic, metallic or gem.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Affinity
entries: At 1st level, choose one of the following damage types; acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison. You have resistance to this damage type.

subclassFeature.name: Chaotic Affinity
entries: {@note Optional Feature which replaces Draconic Affinity}
Starting at 1st level, whenever you finish a short or long rest, roll a d10 and consult the table below. You have resistance to this damage type until the end of your next short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Head
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can use a bonus action to summon a spectral dragon head above or next to your own. The head remains for 1 minute, or until you dismiss it (no action required), after which it vanishes. The head vanishes early if you are incapacitated or you die.

When you create the head, you can use it in one of the ways in the Dragon Head Actions list below. Until the head vanishes, you can use a bonus action on each of your turns to use the head in one of these ways again.
Once you use this feature, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Dragon Head Actions
items: {@bold Bite.} You use the head to make a melee spell attack against a creature within 5ft of you. On a hit, the target takes piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d8} + plus your Charisma modifier. This attack counts as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

{@bold Breath.} You use the head to exhale destructive energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw against your warlock spell save DC, taking {@dice 2d6} damage of the type associated with your Draconic Affinity (or Chaotic Affinity) feature on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

{@bold Grasp.} You use the head to take the {@action Grapple} action against a creature within 10 feet of you. You may use your warlock spell attack modifier in place of your Strength (Athletics) for the contested rolls. You do not require a free hand to grapple a creature in this way and the creature is released if the head vanishes. While you have a creature grappled in this way, you cannot use the head for any other actions, except to release the creature (no action required).
{@bold Preparation.} You prepare the head for upcoming events. You gain one additional reaction until the start of your next turn. You may only take one reaction on each turn in combat.

{@bold Darksight.} You use the head to gain darkvision out to 60ft and gain advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks until the start of your next turn. In addition, you can see through magical darkness while using this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Reflex
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you, or a creature you see within 15ft of you, takes damage of the type associated with your Draconic Affinity (or Chaotic Affinity) feature, you can use a reaction in one of the following ways based on your patron���s dragon form:

items: {@bold Chromatic.} The creature takes an additional {@dice 1d6} damage of the same type. When you reach 10th level in this class, the damage increases to {@dice 2d6}.
{@bold Metallic.} The damage taken by the creature is reduced by {@dice 1d8}. When you reach 10th level in this class, the damage reduced increases to {@dice 2d8}.

{@bold Gem.} The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your warlock spell save DC. On a fail, they are {@condition frightened} by the source of the damage until the end of its next turn. When you reach 10th level in this class, the {@condition frightened} condition lasts for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, removing the condition on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Scaled Wings
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use an action to unfurl a pair of draconic wings and gain a flying speed of 60ft for 10 minutes. You can use this action a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Shape
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can cast the {@spell polymorph|phb} spell on yourself without expending a spell slot. When you cast the spell using this feature, you chose the form of a {@filter dragon whose challenge rating is equal to or less than your level|bestiary|Challenge Rating=[&0;&14]|type=dragon}, rather than a beast. Once you use this feature, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Awakened Energy
entries: Your patron is a being of sentient energy. Perhaps they originate from one of the elemental planes, or the positive or negative energy planes. Perhaps they were once born from magic and have since grown beyond their creators. They may also be ordinary flesh and blood creatures that have become consumed by the very magic they once wielded.
However your patron manifests, you share in a small measure of their energy and power to control it. The energy flows through your body ready to unleash destruction at any moment.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Awakened Energy lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

When you cast one of these spells, you change the damage type to the one associated with your Energetic Affinity feature. When you do so, the appearance of the spell may change to reflect the new type. For example, if you cast the burning hands spell, you might unleash an arc of lightning or a wave of necrotic energy rather than a sheet of flame. If a spell allows you to choose from multiple damage types, you instead add the damage type associated with your Energetic Affinity feature to the list of options if it is not already included.

subclassFeature.name: Energetic Affinity
entries: At 1st level, chose one of the following damage types; acid, cold, fire, lightning, necrotic, poison, psychic, radiant or thunder. You have resistance to that damage type.
Additionally, you gain further benefits when you acquire certain Pact Boons at 3rd level:

items: {@b Pact of the Blade.} You can change your pact weapon's damage type to the chosen type.
{@b Pact of the Chain.} Your familiar gains resistance to the chosen damage type. In addition, you can use your Charged Strike feature with your familiar's attacks.
{@b Pact of the Shield.} While you are wielding your pact shield, any creatures you choose within 5ft of you also have resistance to the chosen damage type.
{@b Pact of the Talisman.} The wearer of your talisman has advantage on saving throws to avoid or reduce damage of the chosen type.
{@b Pact of the Tome.} When you deal damage with a warlock cantrip, you can change the damage type to the chosen type.

subclassFeature.name: Charged Strike
entries: Starting at 1st level, once per turn, when you deal damage to a creature with a weapon or spell, you can deal an extra {@dice 1d6} damage to the target of the type associated with your Energetic Affinity feature.

subclassFeature.name: Destructive Storm
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use an action to surround yourself with a violent storm of energy to a distance of 15 feet. The storm lasts for 1 minute, or until you lose concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell). The storm resembles your Energetic Affinity, such as a cloud of poison gas, a freezing snow storm or a swarm of rude spirits hurling psychic insults.

For the duration, the area is considered heavily obscured. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Constitution saving throw against your warlock spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes a number of {@dice d8}s of damage equal to your proficiency bonus. The damage is of the type associated with your Energetic Affinity feature. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage.

When you create the storm, you can choose a number of creatures that you can see equal to your proficiency bonus. You and the chosen creatures are unaffected by the storm, and consider the area only lightly obscured.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Living Bolt
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use an action to summon a bolt of living energy in an unoccupied space you can see within 30ft. The bolt uses the {@creature living lightning bolt|erlw} statblock, except the damage type for its immunity and its Magical Strike trait and Spell Mimicry traits is replaced by the type associated with your Energetic Affinity feature. The bolt's appearance may also change to resemble the associated type, such as a ray of radiant light or a floating blob of acid. The bolt remains for 1 hour, after which it disappears. It disappears early if it is reduced to 0 hit points, if you dismiss it (no action required), if you use this feature again, or if you are {@condition incapacitated}.

The bolt is an ally to you and your companions, and it acts on your turn. You can use a bonus action to command how the bolt moves and what action it takes on its next turn, or to give it general orders, such as to attack your enemies. In the absence of such orders, it takes the Dodge action and moves to stay within 30ft of you.
You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Energy Affinity
entries: At 14th level, you gain immunity to the damage type associated with your Energetic Affinity feature.

In addition, whenever you are subjected to damage of the associated type, you take no damage and instead absorb some of the energy for future attacks. When you next use your Charged Strike feature before the end of your next turn, the extra damage increases to {@dice 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: The Hivemind
entries: Your patron is not a single entity but a potentially infinite collective of beings across all the planes of reality. These beings pool their power and knowledge into the collective hivemind. Followers of these hiveminds are granted limited access to the collective knowledge of all its beings but still usually retain their own identity and personality.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Hivemind lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Knowledge of the Hive
entries: Starting at 1st level, when you roll for an ability check that uses either your Intelligence or Wisdom modifier, you can call upon the hivemind to gain a bonus to the roll equal to your Charisma modifier. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Network Insight
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can employ the hivemind's drones, senses and memories to find potentially useful tidbits about a creature that may aid you in dealing with them. If you spend 1 minute observing a creature, you can then learn up to two tidbits about the creature. Describe the information you wish to learn, and the DM will decide if you successfully discover this information and what it is (some examples can be seen in the list below). The DM also decides how the information can affect your rolls and gameplay, granting advantage on social checks when using the information would be an appropriate example.

If the creature is disguised, whether by magical or non-magical means, and you are unaware, the DM may decide you learn the characteristics of the persona the creature is presenting rather than their own. Alternatively, they may decide that the hivemind can see through the disguise even if you can't.
Once you use this feature, you cannot use it on the same creature again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Example Tidbits
items: One ability score of your choice.
Their creature type and race, if any.
Their alignment, if any.
An identifying piece of information, such as a name, rank or title.
A piece of information that can be used to falsify a common bond, such as the name of their hometown, a school they attended or a distant family member.
A secret that could potentially be used to blackmail them, such as an extramarital affair, illicit vice or embarrassing hobby.
An address which they visit frequently, such as their home, workplace or favourite tavern.
Their opinion about a particular person, faction or thing.

subclassFeature.name: Hive Magic
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can attempt to cast a spell or cantrip that you don't know. The spell must be 5th level or lower from the warlock spell list, and you must make a Charisma check or the casting fails. The DC for this check equals 12 + the spell's level (DC12 for a cantrip). If the spell is 1st-level or higher, you expend a warlock spell slot, even if the casting fails.

subclassFeature.name: Hive Ritual
entries: {@note Optional feature that replaces the Hive Magic feature}

Starting at 10th level, when you finish a short or long rest, you can choose a spell of 5th level or lower from the Divination school of magic that has the ritual tag. This spell can be from any spell list, but counts as a warlock spell for you. Until the end of your next short or long rest, you can cast this spell as a ritual.

subclassFeature.name: Psychometry
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can spend ten minutes to touch an object or willing creature and witness a scene from the past that it was present for. The scene must have lasted less than ten minutes and have taken place within 30ft of the target during the time of the scene. Describe the time, place or part of the scene you wish to witness, such as "Yesterday at noon" or "When this window was broken". You then witness the scene over the ten minutes. While doing so, you are {@condition blinded|phb} and {@condition deafened|phb}. The scene ends early if you take damage, or become {@condition incapacitated|phb}.

If the target is a creature, you may witness the event using their senses at the time (you can also do this for a corpse that was alive at the time of the scene). If the target is an object, what you witness is limited, you could hear parts of a conversation, see vague images or sense strong emotions. If a creature, object or area in the scene is hidden from divination magic (or was during the time of the scene), you cannot perceive it or anything inside it but may see other elements of the scene. Once you use this feature, you can not do so again until you finish a long rest.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: Choose two from {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill insight} and {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: One type of {@item artisan's tools|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A collar or set of manacles, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt pouch containing 5gp

entries.name: Feature: Hard Knock Life
entries: You are used to living with great difficulty and can survive with next to nothing. You can survive on half the amount of food and water as others.
In addition, when in a settlement larger than a village, you can believably pose as a beggar or pauper to elicit sympathy and get enough food or coppers to live a squalid life at no expense.

entries.name: Thrall Status
entries: You can roll on the table to determine your current status, or chose one that best fits your character.

rows: I am still a thrall in service to a master.
I have escaped my bonds and am now free.
I was rescued from my old masters by someone else.
I was granted my freedom by my old masters.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: As a thrall you are, or were, expected to be submissive and quiet as you carried out your chores and errands without complaint. Some thralls accept this fate while others are more rebelious and openly despise their masters.

rows: I am submissive and often hesitant to complain, make eye contact or speak out of turn.
I call everyone 'sir' or 'lady' without really thinking about it.
I automatically start doing chores like cleaning out of habit.
I am terrified of ropes, chains and whips.
I look out for my friends and allies.
I am rebellious and hate being told what to do.
I want to prove my strength by subjugating my own thralls. (Evil)
People should respect and obey their betters. (Lawful)
Thralldom is a cruel tradition that should not exist. (Good)
No one should have authority over others. (Chaotic)
I just want to leave my past behind and lead my own life. (Neutral)
I want to make something of my life, I will be a somebody. (Any)
I want revenge on those who hold/held me in bondage, at any cost.
Despite everything, I still feel a sense of loyalty to my masters.
I owe everything to those who freed me.
I am my own master now, I owe nothing to anyone.
I feel a kinship with anyone who has suffered as a thrall and wish to help them however I can.
I long to return to my old life and family before I became a thrall, or at least whatever is left of them.
The cruelty of my masters has made me nervous and shy in social situations.
I tend to go along with others unquestioningly, even when I disagree with them.
I value my own life as lesser and more expendable than those around me.
I have a habit of stealing food as I fear I'll go hungry otherwise.
I am overly protective of my belongings and refuse to share, even with close friends.
I distrust people as I fear everyone I meet is secretly trying to make me their own thrall.

entries: You are, or were, a thrall to a particular individual or clan in the Northlands. Thralls are the lowest sapient beings on the social ladder, they are the slaves and serfs of the clan.

Most thralls are basic labourers such as farmers, miners and haulers. A few are put into service as house servants, concubines and cooks. Especially strong and loyal thralls may end up as housecarls, bodyguards and even raiders in their own right.
Sometimes entire hamlets and villages are held as thralls to a nearby clan under threat of raiding. Though particular individuals may also be seized and taken home to serve as personal thralls.

Even under the kindest masters, the life of a thrall is hard. You have, or had, no freedom or possessions and had to make do with whatever food and clothing your masters allow. You are, or were, expected to serve without complaint with your life as the only reward.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Intimidation}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: One type of {@item gaming set|phb} or {@item musical instrument|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A helmet or set of bracers bearing the sigil of your clan, a {@item gaming set|phb} or {@item musical instrument|phb} of your choice, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt pouch containing 10gp

entries.name: Feature: Hearth and Home
entries: Provided you are still welcome, you can always find free food and lodging of a modest standard for you and your companions when in a settlement owned by your clan. Those who fear your clan's banners may also provide food and lodging if you agree to not burn down their homes.

entries.name: Role In Raider Crew
entries: All raiders are expected to fight but usually also have more specialised roles. You can roll on the table to determine why, or chose one that best fits your character.

rows: Skald, horn blower or war drummer
Support staff (cook, blacksmith, or the like)

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Raiders are battle hardened warriors who strike fear into the hearts of their victims, possessing unwavering determination and fury in battle. Many raiders claim to not fear death as a good, honourable death is the ultimate goal of any raider.

rows: Nothing brings me more joy than the heat of battle.
I am extremely loyal to my clan and it's traditions.
I can get very competitive in almost everything I do.
I enjoy battles of wit as much as I enjoy battles of blood.
I am always the loudest and merriest one at a feast.
I like to resolve matters quickly, even if my solutions seem hasty.
I live everyday as if it is my last, because it could well be.
I take great care in my appearance, if I die today I want to look good doing it.
The strong take what they want, the weak suffer what they must. (Evil)
I must obey my jarl, even if I don't like their demands. (Lawful)
We should only take from those who can spare it or don't deserve what they have. (Good)
Only the gods have true authority over my life, jarls and banners mean little to me. (Chaotic)
The prosperity of one's clan is all that matters, however you choose to provide for it. (Neutral)
One day, all the mead halls in the land will be filled with songs of my glory. (Any)
I serve my jarl and my clan, I have no other loyalties.
My loyalty lies with my crewmates, no one else.
I have someone back home that I hope I can provide for with the treasures I seize.
My clan's jarl is a weak or cruel ruler I will see them punished or usurped if I can.
I still hold a grudge against another raider or clan for what they did to me.
I can't help but take what I want, even when I am not raiding.
I am haunted by memories of something I did or saw during a raid.
I often lose control in the heat of battle.
If someone questions my courage or honour, I will never back down no matter how dangerous the situation.
I can get very agressive when I'm drunk, and I'm drunk often.
While I claim not to fear death, I am actually terrified of it.

entries: You are a raider for your clan in The Northlands. You lead a brutal and violent life constantly just an axe swing away from death, but it's worth it. The treasure you bring back to your clan grants you much glory and renown.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Intimidation}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies
items.entry: One type of {@item gaming set|phb}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A ceremonial circlet or diadem (A mark of your ascension to Amazon), a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt pouch containing 15gp

entries.name: Restriction: Female Only
entries: Only women can become Amazons, men are exiled or slaughtered once they have fulfilled their purpose.

entries.name: Feature: Amazon Pride
entries: Amazons are well revered warriors. Whether you are loved or feared, you find that people are often willing to be more lenient with prices and services.
Provided you are still welcome with the Amazons, you can expect free lodging and food for you and your companions within Amazon camps, so long as the men don't stay too long.

entries.name: Reason For Leaving
entries: You have been separated from your tribe for some reason. You can roll on the table to determine why, or chose one that best fits your character.

rows: I was sent on a special mission by my queen, one only I could complete.
I was captured and later escaped, I am trying to find my tribe again.
I was shunned and exiled for refusing to kill/leave my mate/son.
The tribe brings back painful memories, I had to leave.
I am searching for artefacts and allies to help my tribe.
I disagreed with the tribe and decided to go my own way.
I am the only surviving member of my tribe, I am searching for other Amazon tribes.
I simply wanted to explore the world.
I speak down to all men as if they are animals.
I only know war and wilderness, social etiquette and commerce are alien to me.
I am constantly looking for a fight to prove myself to strangers.
The sight of people living ordinary lives amuses me for some reason.
I am always ready for battle, I don't have time for bathing or looking nice.
I don't like subterfuge, I will not lie and hate when others lie.
The simplest, most direct method is usually the best.
I like to scare companions with stories from my life with the tribe.
I only value strength, I care not for morals or wisdom. (Evil)
I must follow the customs and laws of my tribe, even if I don't like it. (Lawful)
I must use what strength I have to serve the greater good. (Good)
I refuse to follow orders I disapprove of. (Chaotic)
An honourable enemy can always become a good friend. (Neutral)
Ambition, I will be more than just another woman, I will be legendary. (Any)
I serve my queen, I have no other loyalties.
I will serve Ares to my dying breath.
No man shall ever rule me.
My tribe is wrong about men, I shall never shun/execute an innocent man.
I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
To surrender in battle is the greatest shame I can feel.
I made a terrible mistake in battle that cost many lives-and I would do anything to keep that mistake secret.
My hatred of my enemies is blinding and unreasoning.
I obey my queen, even when I disagree with the order.
I refuse to follow the laws of the lands beyond my tribe, this constantly gets me in trouble.

entries: You hail from a famous tribe of warrior women known as the Amazons. Amazons pride themselves on their strength and independence. Men are not permitted among their ranks and are only used for breeding.

Some tribes have agreements with neighbouring tribes and settlements in which, once a year the strongest men are chosen to mate with the Amazons. Any girls born from this union are raised as Amazons themselves while the boys are sent back to their fathers.
In more aggressive tribes, men are captured during raids, enslaved and then slaughtered after the deed is done. Any boys resulting from these unions are usually killed or abandoned.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies
items.entry: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Religion}

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One exotic language of your choice (agreed with the DM).

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A bottle of black ink, a quill, a small knife, a ring or amulet signifying your membership in the Magi of Hecate, a set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, and a belt pouch containing 10gp.

entries.name: Feature: Magi Membership
entries: If you are still welcome with the Magi, you can rely on certain benefits that membership provides. You can meet up with colleagues in most settlements larger than a village. These colleagues can help you find information, jobs and make connections to potential allies and patrons. You can usually find enough odd jobs to fund a modest lifestyle with the Magi's help.
You may also earn small discounts when procuring services from other magi, such as performing certain spells, buying and crafting magic items or hiring tutors and mercenaries.

You must pay dues of 5 gp per month to the Magi of Hecate. If you miss payments, you must make up back dues to remain in the Magi's good graces. If you miss too many payments, you may be expelled and need to earn your way back in to regain the benefits of membership.

entries.name: Magus Specialism
entries: Some magi have specialist roles and tend towards jobs aligning with their specialisms. You can select your specialism from the table below or roll randomly, you may also come up with your own.

rows: Repairing tools and furniture and performing basic tasks for people.
Performing party tricks, conjuring wine and fireworks.
Making and identifying potions and poisons.
Collecting, trading and studying magic items and records.
Mending wounds, curing diseases and breaking curses.
Creating magic items, glyphs and wards.
Training mages, from beginners to experts.
Fighting, supporting expeditions or training magically-enhanced troops.
Study of magic creatures and extra-planar beings.
Experimenting and studying new spells and magic.
Advisor to political, religious and military leaders, particularly on subjects related to magic.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Generally, most magi have experience with magic and are accomplished spellcasters, though this is not technically a requirement, the study of magic or magic items is usually enough to grant you membership. Despite their official devotion to Hecate, the magi tend to be more academic or vocational than religious.

rows: I always listen deeply and think carefully before speaking.
I am often insulted by the petty requests common people make of magi, they are a waste of my talents.
I find my work or study far more interesting than dealing with people.
I quote (or misquote) sacred texts and proverbs in almost every situation.
I add a magical flair to almost everything I do, even simple activities like eating a meal or opening a book.
I am always trying to talk people into hiring my services, even when they don't need them.
I don't part with my money easily and will haggle tirelessly to get the best deal possible.
I look down upon those who don't (or can't) use magic.
Generosity. My talents were given to me so that I could use them to benefit the world. (Good)
Law. Magic should be used to enforce the laws of both gods and mortals. (Lawful)
Knowledge. Improving personal and public knowledge should always be a goal, no matter who uses it. (Neutral)
Change. Magic is a tool with which anyone can change the world. (Chaotic)
Gain. I joined the magi solely to seek power, influence or wealth, that desire still drives me above all others. (Evil)
Aspiration. I seek to prove myself a worthy magus to the world and to Hecate herself. (Any)
I adore some or all of my colleagues and will do whatever I can to help them.
Protecting, and providing for, my clients or students is my highest priority.
My workshop or study is one place I feel truly safe and comfortable.
Everything I do, I do to impress a specific person.
My life's work is pursuing or protecting the answer to some great mystery.
I have a rival magus, I will do all I can to be better than them.
My curiosity regarding unknown magics can often lead me into danger.
I'm quick to assume that someone is trying to cheat me.
I always expect to be treated like nobility, even where I have no such authority or status.
I frequently overwork myself at the cost of sleeping or eating properly.
I am never wrong, even when I am.
I fear that I am a fraud and can never live up to the praise and expectations placed upon me.

entries: You are, or were, a member of the much exalted Magi of Hecate, a group of acolytes and academics studying magic and magic items as well as providing magical services, for a fee. Many magi may try to distance themselves from their reputation as mages-for-hire or mercenaries but even magi need money.

It is common for groups of magi to covene in and around temples, shrines and academic institutions to exchange services, knowledge and to collaborate in arcane research and work. Magi can be found in such places in most cities and large towns.

deity.name: Chaos
deity.title: The Original Entity
entries: Chaos was the first entity to exist, they are older than the cosmos itself. To worship Chaos is to worship absence and nothingness. Chaos does not grant any boons or rewards for worship.

customProperties.Typical Forms: Aasimar, Currently Incorporeal in the pit of Tartarus
Triton, Water Elemental, Merman, Giant Crab

deity.name: Prometheus
deity.title: Father of Humans
deity.province: Creator of Humans, Dwarves, Elves and Orcs

customProperties.Typical Forms: Elf, Aasimar, Manifestation of viewer's desires

deity.name: Apollo
deity.title: Lord of Music
deity.province: Music, Lyre, Poetry, Archery, The Sun, Prophecies and Oracles

customProperties.Worshipers: Bards, Poets, Oracles, Fortune Tellers, Archers, Temples

deity.name: Athena
deity.title: Lady of Wisdom
deity.province: Wisdom, Martial Strategy, Politics and Elves

customProperties.Worshipers: Warriors, Amazons, Generals, Politicians, Scholars, Elves
Performers, Whore, Hedonists, Innkeepers, Vineyards, Temples
Smiths, Tinkers, Firewielders, Dwarves, Warforged, Temples

deity.name: Hera
deity.title: Lady of Marriage
deity.province: Women, Marriage, Family, Punishing Adulterers and Bigamists

deity.name: Hermes
deity.title: Lord of Messengers
deity.province: Thieves, Messengers, Travellers, Shepherds, Medicine, Psychopomp for Great Heroes

customProperties.Worshipers: Thieves, Messengers, Travellers, Shepherds, Physicians, Temples

deity.name: Zeus
deity.title: Lord of the Sky
deity.province: King of Olympians, The Sky, Lighting, Xenia, Kings

customProperties.Worshipers: Undertakers, Graveyard Keepers, Necromancers, Temples, Cultists, Assassins
Mages, Scholars of Magic, Some Temples

deity.name: Thanatos
deity.title: The Soul Guide
deity.province: Personification of Death, Psychopomp for dead souls

deity.name: Rexus
deity.title: The Dragon King
entries: Rexus is the leader of the Iuris Legion.

deity.name: Sophus
deity.title: The Scholar
deity.province: Knowledge, wisdom, art and divine punishment through magic, curses and madness

deity.name: Idex
deity.title: The Judge
deity.province: Justice and divine punishment through execution, imprisonment and violence

deity.name: Ferrarius
deity.title: The Smith
deity.province: Forging, masonry, engineering, constructs and divine punishment through fire and explosions

deity.name: Pestas
deity.title: The Storm
deity.province: Storms, the fog and divine punishment through extreme weather and natural disasters
entries: Supposedly sent the fog to punish mortals on the orders of Rexus.

deity.name: Vitas
deity.title: The Protector
entries: Saved a small number of mortals from the fog to start anew.

deity.name: Ricola
deity.title: The Alchemist
deity.province: Alchemy, chemistry and divine punishment through disease and poison

deity.name: Scurra
deity.title: The Jester
deity.province: Cunning, espionage, theatre, comedy and divine punishment through ridicule and defamation
entries: While sometimes considered the ���black sheep��� of the Legion, some claim it was Scurra who discovered how to ascend to godhood, granting her a place within the Legion.

deity.name: Mutter
deity.title: The Mother
deity.province: The natural world (Debauchery in Caligos Imperium)
entries: The Mother is vast network of ever expanding roots that form the world itself.

deity.name: Vater
deity.title: The Father
deity.province: Life, family and the sky (Tyranny in Caligos Imperium)
entries: Vater was a rogue root of Mutter that grew upwards and outwards to form the braches that make up the sky. From these branches came life.

deity.name: Wasserie
deity.title: The River, Aspect of Mutter
deity.province: Water and uncertainty (Anarchy in Caligos Imperium)

deity.name: Geierin
deity.title: The Night, Aspect of Mutter
deity.province: Night, magic and curses (Dark magic in Caligos Imperium)

customProperties.Typical Forms: The Moon, Giant Spider, Giant Moth

deity.name: Feus
deity.title: The Warm Winds, Aspect of Mutter
deity.province: Day, warmth and fire (Droughts and arson in Caligos Imperium)

deity.name: Eiskel
deity.title: The Cold Winds, Aspect of Mutter
deity.province: Cold winds, snow and ice (Apocalypse in Caligos Imperium)

deity.name: Maulich
deity.title: The Elk, Aspect of Vater
deity.province: Prey, plantlife and agriculture (Weakness and sloth in Caligos Imperium)

deity.name: Olfus
deity.title: The Wolf, Aspect of Vater
deity.province: Predators, hunting and strength of the pack (Violence and savagry in Caligos Imperium)

deity.name: Zornlich
deity.title: The Bull, Aspect of Vater
deity.province: Fury, passion, determination and music (Brutality and destruction in Caligos Imperium)

deity.name: Sepulcrus
deity.title: The Hare, Aspect of Vater
deity.province: Death and the afterlife (Necromancy and infernals in Caligos Imperium)

deity.name: Talitus
deity.title: The Entropic Entity
deity.province: Time, entropy and mortality (Chaos and pure evil in Caligos Imperium)
entries: Talitus does not directly belong to either the Anarchium or the Iuris Legion. They are the god of time, entropy and death. They represent the inevitable end of everything, even the gods.

There are no statues or temples of Talitus as they have no known form or gender, nor are they known to speak to mortals. Very rarely, Talitus will choose a mortal to perform a task, the purposes of these tasks are known only to Talitus.

Somewhat paradoxically, Talitus is perpetually the youngest and oldest entity in the universe. Taltius may be one, many or even none. Scholar���s have spent centuries trying to understand the very few clues they have about Talitus.

Talitus worship is deeply taboo across the entire Caligos Archipelago. Worshipping them is seen as praying for the death of everything, including the gods. In the Caligos Imperium, any evidence implying worship of Talitus is an instant death sentence.

language.name: Cyrik
entries: Cyrik is the most prevalent language in Cyranos, most residents will know at least some of it.
Naturally Cyrik comes in many dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Upper Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Nobles academics and artists, especially in western regions
Upper Cyrik is a refined dialect often utilising longer and more descriptive words than those found in other dialects.

entries.name: Lower Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Commonfolk in cities and towns, especially in north and western regions
Lower Cyrik employs a wide variety of slang terms, often with vague literal meanings, relying heavily on context and tone.

entries.name: Eastern Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Commonfolk in cities and towns, especially in eastern regions

Eastern Cyrik is similar to Lower Cyrik, though it tends to be much shorter and blunter. Despite this, a lot can be conveyed through subtext. Arkians are especially renowned for short and blunt remarks that convey enormous subtext.

entries.name: Drakon Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Draconic and Reptilian people, especially in Ormux and Emeris
Believed to be partly derived from Draconic, Drakon is a dialect common with draconic and reptilian peoples, being well suited to their physiology.

entries.name: Northern Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents from north eastern Cyranos, especially in and around Illys
With significant migrations to and from The Northlands, Vrakos, Thalia and Trenin, Northern Cyrik borrows many terms from languages of these regions.

language.name: Gailian
entries: Gailian, also known as Ageton, is a harsh language common on Agetos Major, especially in Gailum and within the Gailum Tribes. The language originates with the Gailum Tribes, who roam around Agetos Major and occasionally meeting in Gailum, which also led to the founding of the city. The language is still heavily used by the tribes and those who frequently trade and communicate with them.

Gailian is rather tonal langauges with grunts and growls allowing for surprisingly complex communication. There are many scripts for Gaillian, with many tribes having their own unique ones, often derived from wood and stone carvings. The scripts generally have enough similarities that understanding one is enough to understand the others. Gailian does not have any strict distinctions between first, second or third person, often relying on names descriptions or gestures to clarify the subject of a sentence. Native speakers sometimes struggle to adapt to this feature in other languages resulting in grammatical oddities, such as refering to themselves in third person or even others in first or second.
Like many languages, Gailian has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: City Tongue
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Urban residents of Gailum, especially orcs

City Tongue is a dialect of Gailian that use more closely resembles Cyrik, with fewer grunts and reliance on tone, making translations between them easier. City Tongue developed when traders began forming the permanent settlement that became the city of Gailum.

entries.name: Old Tongue
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Members of the Gailum Tribes, especially orcs
The Old Tongue is a more traditional form of the language developed by disconnected tribes occasionally crossing paths. As such, tone and context are often more important than literal meanings.

entries.name: Goblin Tongue
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Goblins across Agetos Major

The goblin tongue features fewer article words or distinction between tenses, gender or quantity. It is occasionally mocked as primitive or stupid, despite being just as nuanced as other dialects and languages.

language.name: Vrakon
entries: Vrakon is the tongue of Vrakos and the surrounding area. Much of civilisation in this area is deep underground. Both the written and spoken versions of Vrakon are well adapted to legibility in dark and dusty caverns, even with muffles and echos of such places.
Like many languages, Vrakon has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Crystal Voice
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Upper class residents of Vrakos, as well as merchants and bards

Crystal Voice is a refined and almost poetic dialect of Vrakon often spoken by nobles, merchants and performers.
