Combining clever wordplay and rhymes, a pleasing accent and Crystal Voice can make speakers seem more likeable and trustworthy. Using Crystal Voice properly, especially in verse, can actually be quite difficult and may require elocution lessons.

entries.name: Stone Voice
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Common residents of Vrakos, especially those from lower layers

Stone Tongue is a more common and accessable dialect of Vrakon than Crystal Voice. It features a more diverse selection a slang terms, many of which might be considered crude, vulgur or even offensive to native speakers of Crystal Voice.

language.name: Thalian
entries: Thailian is the language of the smiths and other residents of Thalia, a volcanic island in the Sea of Cyranos. While it is a unique language in its own right, its origins in Vrakon, Celestial and Primordial are noticable. The langauge notably contains lots of technical jargon and idioms based on craftwork.
Like many languages, Thalian has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Organic Thalian
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents of Thalia, especially dwarves and cyclopes
As the name would suggest, Organic Thalian is a dialect used most often by organic creatures of Thalia, as opposed the many constructs that originate there.

entries.name: Phaeston Thalian
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Warforged and other constructs made on Thalia

The Phaeston dialect has slighlty more in common with Celestial than other dialects. It is often used in magic charms and rituals. And is also often spoken by contructs originating from Thalia, especially those with limited personality and identity beyond their initial purpose. Phaeston features less slang, contractions and reliance on tone or sub-text than many languages.

language.name: Sign
entries: Sign language is a language that does not rely upon spoken or written word, instead using gestures to convey meanings. Sign is common among those with hearing or speech impairments, as well as between peoples who differing physiologies make sharing a spoken language difficult.
Like many languages, Sign has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Poetic Sign
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Performers and nobles

Poetic Sign is almost more a performance than a language. It contains many dance-like manoeuvres using the entire body rather than just hands and face. It may have been created by performers wanting to convey messages to audiences without worrying about language barriers.

entries.name: Western Sign
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents of western Cyranos
Western Sign is a simplified, and more practical version of poetic sign. Featuring far lass full body movements, relying almost entirely on head and hand movements.

entries.name: Eastern Sign
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents of eastern Cyranos, especially military folk

Many military folk learn at least some of this dialect in order to communicate simple messages while trying to be quiet or otherwise being drowned out by the noise of battle. However, learning more of the dialect can allow communication in wider contexts.

entries.name: Sign Language and verbal spellcasting
entries: Providing verbal components of spells using sign is very difficult, most creatures who learn sign as a second language cannot do it. However, at the DM's discretion, a creature may be able to do it, effectively replacing verbal components with somatic ones. The DM may decide that certain spells still require facial expressions, exhalations or noise, preventing gagged or silenced creatures from using them.

language.name: Elbros
entries: Elbros is a western language often considered the language of the elves, though many speak it. The language has clear influences from the languages of the Pelais Coast
Like many languages, Elbros has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Higher Elbros
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Elven nobles, especially in Nyria and Halosini

Higher Elbros is sometimes considered the more refined and regal of the Elbros dialects. It bears notable ancestry from the elven languages of the Pelais Coast, as well as Upper Cyrik with long, descriptive words and less shorthand slang.

entries.name: Woodlands Elbros
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Tribal communities in the northern and western forests, especially those composed of elves and creatures of fey origin

Not unlike Higher Elbros, Woodlands Elbros bears notable ancestry from the languages of the Pelais Coast. It also shows signs of ancestry from Druidic and Sylvan, sometimes incorporating animal-like clicks and whistles to affect tone and subtext.

entries.name: Plain Elbros
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Elven commoners, especially those in cities and towns

Plain Elbros is the most common dialect of Elbros used within the cities and towns of Cyranos. With other dialects of Elbros have borrowed from local languages, especially Upper Cyrik, Plain Elbros does so to a much greater degree, and from a wider variety of dialects, particulary other variants of Cyrik. This makes Plain Elbros sound much more native to Cyrik speakers, compared to other dialects of Elbros which can sound foreign even when spoken by natives of Cyranos.

language.name: Sea Speak
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Travellers and sailors all across Cyranos and beyond

Sea Speak is sometimes confusing mix of many languages, allowing simple communication between people all across Alvergia. Borrowing words and structures from multiple languages and dialects, it lacks consistency and can be confusing when trying to communicate anything beyond the simplest phrases.

language.name: Fiendish
entries: Fiends have limited influence the Sea of Cyranos, many of them being monsters, or descendants of monsters, that have long since been defeated and killed or sealed in the Underworld. However, some still roam free, as do their followers and those who study them.
Like many languages, Fiendish has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Abyssal
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Chaotic fiends, such as demons

Abyssal is more blunt and direct dialect of Fiendish. While articulating complex concepts is difficult in abyssal, most creatures can convey basic messages, especially threats, very quickly and efficiently.
While many scripts can be used for Abyssal, writers tend to use simpler ones that can be written quickly and crudely on stone or clay.

entries.name: Infernal
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Lawful fiends, such as devils

Infernal is a more complex, elegant form of Fiendish. It is also filled with homonyms, and words of multiple meanings, allowing for crafty wordplay. This is especially useful when attempting to trick and confuse others with verbal or written promises and contracts. It has sometimes been rumored that it is impossible to outright lie in Infernal, either because of some curse or because there are so many grammatical loopholes that anything can be interepted in multiple ways.
While many scripts can be used for Infernal, writers tend to use more complex, cursive scripts that require special ink, or blood, to write properly and remain legible.

language.name: Celestial
entries: Celestial is the holy language of Olympians, Titans and their disciples.
Like many languages, Celestial has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Olympian
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Olympians and those associated with them
The most common variant of Celestial is Olympian, given the Olympians are the current ruling class of the gods. It is closer to Cyrik than other dialacts, being one of its primary ancestor languages.

entries.name: Hadian
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Underworld dwellers and followers of Hades

Hades has always been a little estranged from his family, not joining the Olympian council and dwelling mostly in his own realm, the Underworld, rather than the Upper Sky. Naturally this has led to variantions in dialect between the godly realms. Hadian is the dialect of those who dwell below, those who serve Hades and his Queen, Persephone. Followers in the mortal realm often speak Hadian is hushed tones or even silent mouthing. Mortal speakers are often distrusted as they are associated with worshippers of Hades and death.

entries.name: Titanic
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Titans and those associated with them

Titanic is the earliest form of Celestial, derrived from the first Titans as they usurped their Primordial parents as the ruling class of gods. Historians sometimes see this as the bridge between Primordial and Celestial, with many similarities and some, seemingly intentional changes. Not unlike Hadian, Titanic is mildly controversial in the mortal world due to its association with titans, many of whom are seen as diposed tyrants.

language.name: Deep Speech
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Aberations

Deep speech is the language of aberations and those who should not exist, at least according to the rules of reality as defined by gods. It does not have defined words or grammar, rather focused projections of emotions that confuse and terrify those unfamiliar. However, there does appear to be at least some structure and it can be used to convey incredibly complex topics, possibly better than any other language, provided you don't go mad attempting to understand it.

language.name: Draconic
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Dragons and dragon worshippers

Draconic is the language of dragons, however, among mortals it seen as a mostly ceremonial language found in prayers, mottos and holy texts. It is considered a holy language by the followers of Drakon Olympus, far more so than Celestial.

language.name: Druidic
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Druids and the Wild Peoples

Druidic is langauge that attempts to articulate the thoughts and emotions of nature and primal creatures. It is most often used by druids and those within the various tribes collectively known as the Wild Peoples.

The scripts of Druidic are often intentionally designed so they can't be written by carving or otherwise damaging plants and earth. Instead requiring magic or careful effort to encourage plants to grow certain ways or ensuring the message will naturally wash away without affecting the natural order.

language.name: Primordial
entries: Primordial is the language of the Primordial gods and monsters, as well as elementals. It is a gutteral language
Like many languages, Primordial has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Ancient
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Primordial gods and monsters

entries.name: Auran
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Air elementals and monsters

entries.name: Aquan
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Water elementals and monsters

entries.name: Ignan
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Fire elementals and monsters

entries.name: Terran
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Earth elementals and monsters

language.name: Sylvan
entries: Sylvan is the language of the wilds, particularly on the Isle of Pan, the home of the fey.
Like many languages, Sylvan has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Various Dialects
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Fey creatures and Wild Peoples

Near every forest, desert, river or mountain range that is home to fey or Wild Peoples will have its own dialect of Sylvan that can be instinctively understood by all those the area accepts. Knowing the respective dialect of a natural region appears to give those who know it a heightened sense of awareness while navigating there. Hearing the wind through the trees and what it has to say can guide your path. If one is exiled from such a place by the nature spirits or fey, one might be robbed of their ability to understand the dialect beyond the basics, making them feel like a stranger in a once familar land.

entries.name: Undersylvan
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Underground fey dwellers, such as drow cultists of Arachne

Undersylvan is a dialect of Sylvan often used by fey creatures who prefer the darkness, or who have been forced there. Truely fluent speakers can whisper the dialect in such a way as be heard from great distances underground, sometimes masking their true direction or numbers with the echoes of the dark.

language.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Thieves, spies and criminals

Thieves' cant is a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows messages to be hidden in seemingly normal conversation or writing. Only a creature that knows thieves' cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

language.name: Tactile
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Sight impaired people
Tactile is a written language designed to be read by touching alone, making it especially useful to those with sight impairments or those who wish to read without looking.

language.name: Olfactory
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Beast-like peoples with keen senses of smell

Smells can be used to communicate very simple messages to those with a keen sense of smell. Beast-like humanoids have learned to codify this in some way, often using special absorbent paper, various perfumes and even their own naturally produced smells. Precision is difficult with these languages, often only simple emotions and concepts can be conveyed. Though, smells can be used to emphasize messages written in other languages. For example, in warning signs, amorous letters or hate mail.

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Indulger)
entries: You have developed a high tolerance for intoxicating substances. You gain the following benefits:

items: You have resistance to poison damage and advantage on saving throws to avoid the {@condition poisoned} condition.
You can cast the {@spell detect poison and disease|phb} spell as a ritual.

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Charmer)
entries: Your social skills are greatly enhanced when drink is involved. You gain the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on social checks with non-hostile creatures whilst at least one of you is inebriated by alcohol or other recreational substances.

When a creature makes a saving throw against being {@condition charmed} by you, you can impose disadvantage on the saving throw. Once you do so, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Enchanter)
entries: You have learned new skills with magical theatrics that always please the crowd. You gain the following benefits:

items: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the following list; {@spell bazoz's spicy water|J:General}, {@spell dancing lights|phb}, {@spell druidcraft|phb}, {@spell light}, {@spell minor illusion|phb}, {@spell prestidigitation|phb} and {@spell thaumaturgy|phb}.

You learn {@filter one 1st-level spell of your choice from the enchantment or illusion school of magic.|spells|level=1|school=e;i} You can cast the spell without a spell slot, and you must finish a long rest before you can cast it in this way again. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

entries: Your spellcasting ability for these spalls is Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma (choose when you gain the blessing).

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Performer)
entries: You have developed you party tricks into useful skills. You gain the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency in one skill or tool of your choice. Alternatively you can choose two gaming sets or musical instruments.

Choose one skill or tool in which you have proficiency. You gain expertise with that skill or tool, which means your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with it. The skill or tool you choose must be one that isn't already benefiting from a feature, such as Expertise, that doubles your proficiency bonus.

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Drinkmaster)
entries: You have somehow acquired access to a demiplane containing the personal stash of one the god's entourage.

As an action, you can transform a pitcher or small barrel into an {@item alchemy jug|dmg}. The jug remains magical until the next dawn, and once you create a jug in this way, you cannot do so again until the next dawn. When you use the jug to produce alcoholic drinks, you can produce up to five times as much as normal. In addition to the normal liquids you can produce a wide range of alcoholic substances such as cider, rum, whisky and mead (at the same quantity you produce wine).

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Daredevil)
entries: You have developed a taste and talent for performing dangerous stunts to impress those around you. You gain the following benefits:

items: Increase you Dexterity or Constitution score by 1, to a max of 20.
You can hold your breath for twice as long.

As an action, you can use a {@item oil (flask)|phb|flask of oil} to coat yourself in flammable liquid and ignite it. For the next minute, or until you extinguish the fire as an action, you are wreathed in flames that do not harm you (you ignore the normal effects of the item). While you have these flames, your melee weapon attacks deal an extra {@dice 1d6} fire damage and you have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks against creatures that can see you and that are not immune to fire damage. In addition, when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack or ends its turn {@condition grappled} by you, it takes {@dice 1d6} fire damage.

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Tattoo)
entries: Your inhibited decision making somehow led you to getting a magic tattoo.

You gain {@filter one common or uncommon tattoo of your choice (excluding spellwrought tattoos).|items|type=tattoo|rarity=common;uncommon} If you unattune to the tattoo, it remains on your skin but becomes inert and grants no benefits until you attune to it again.

reward.name: Blessing of the Drunkard (Forgetful)
entries: You infuse your magic with the numbed senses of inebriation. You gain the following benefits:

items: You know the {@spell gift of gab|ai} spell. You can cast the spell without a spell slot, and you must finish a long rest before you can cast it in this way again. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

When a creature fails an Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma against a spell you cast, you can make them forget that they saw you cast the spell. The creature may still be aware that a spell was cast on them but not who cast it. You can cause a creature to forget in this way a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
